Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Controlled Membranes for Industrial Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will take closer to implementation fundamental research results in the technology of actively controlled membranes. By leveraging structures, materials, sensing and feedback control into membrane technology the project could advance fundamental as well as applied knowledge in all these areas. Via the envisioned controlled membrane devices, which will embed very recent theoretical and technological advances, this project will bring research much faster out of University Labs into the applications area and to the market. Dedicated software tools for integrated modeling and design of controlled membrane structures enhance this technology. These tools can enable certain software developers to move away from the traditional sequential approach in which each step of the modeling and design process is rather separated from other steps. The control design step is in general particularly isolated, since control design is performed after all the previous modeling and design steps have been completed. Integrated software tools will enable the multidisciplinary design approach that is nowadays facilitated by growing computational capabilities.

The project may impact the field of optics by providing lightweight, adaptive solutions to replace existing technology that uses heavy, glassy reflectors. Since reflectors are widely used, from space telescopes to light amplifiers in surgery rooms, the societal impact may also be multi-faceted, ranging from improved science data gathering (e.g. via space telescopes) which will enhance scientific understanding of the general public, defense capabilities (in aerospace applications), to health care equipment and conditions. Software for controlled membranes may also impact software developers by providing new, dedicated tools to address the emerging technology of lightweight controlled membrane structures. The project also has the potential to impact biology/medicine because researchers in these areas may use the software to analyze membrane behavior in biological contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project's principal goal was to determine the transition/commercialization readiness level for technology related to controlled membranes using the customer discovery process. Another goal was to use the information gathered through the project's activities to eventually re-define some future research directions such that our research addresses identified barriers and is relevant for applications with potential for commercialization. Another goal was to train the project personnel in entrepreneurial activities.

The numerous customer interviews that we conducted resulted in a rich data set that enabled an informed decision about the commercialization readiness of the envisioned products. Also presentations made and interactions with diverse parties interested in the proposed technology led to a much better understanding of the customer needs related to this technology and of the current entrepreneurial landscape. It was thus found that the originally envisioned products in the area of controlled membranes were too ambitious and not yet ready for commercialization. However it was also found that a potentially sustainable customer base exists and could be further developed.

Another major finding of the project was that the major barrier appears to be the fact that accurate, reliable control oriented modeling, control design, and technology tools for very large systems such as those required for membranes are not mature enough. This prevents rapid development of robust, scalable, cost effective products like the ones we initially envisioned. Such product features are essential in order to sustain a start-up company. More effort has to be devoted to basic as well as applied research in this area to remedy the aforementioned deficiencies. Following the lessons learned from the project's experience we are now able to redefine some of our research directions and address the identified barriers.

The project personnel was trained in many aspects of entrepreneurship and customer discovery and developed a much better understanding of the activities required of a successful start-up company and of the challenges associated with taking advanced technology to the market. By the nature of the project, which requires numerous interviews, presentations, contacts, dissemination of the project results and associated technology was intensive and very effective. Diverse segments of the public were reached, ranging from non-technical to very highly technically trained persons. The project also supported publications and a Ph.D. thesis related to the project's technology.
